sec.div: The spatial-economic framework in five steps
sec.p:
The analytical strategy we adopted involved five steps resumed in Fig. 1: (1) setting a group of ecological/biological criteria to identify ecological optimal areas; (2) setting an economic criterion to identify economically optimal areas; (3) using Bayesian models to identify and predict species distribution; (4) overlapping the ecologically and economically optimal areas to identify the possible levels of conflict between conservation and economic interests using different thresholds, and (5) computing fishers’ economic losses for each proposed scenario assuming that the ecologically optimal area will be closed to fishing.
Figure 1
Diagram of the five steps of the analytical procedure adopted. For fisher’s economic loss x ij denotes the profit for each longitude i and latitude j comprised between the 90% percentile and the maximum value.
